product_name: Standard Fire and Special Perils Insurance

questions.guidance_text: Enter your company's full legal name exactly as it appears on your registration certificate or GST certificate. This ensures proper identification and claim settlement. For example, if registered as 'ABC Manufacturing Private Limited', enter the complete name including the legal suffix.

Your 15-character GST identification number is essential for tax compliance and verification. It starts with a 2-digit state code followed by your PAN and other identifiers. This helps insurers verify your business registration and location.

Provide the full name of the person authorized to handle insurance matters for your company. This person will receive all policy communications and will be the primary point of contact for claims and renewals.

Enter a 10-digit Indian mobile number that's actively monitored. This number will receive important SMS alerts about policy status, renewal reminders, and claim updates. Ensure this number belongs to the authorized contact person.

Provide an official email address that's checked regularly. Policy documents, premium invoices, and claim correspondence will be sent to this email. Using a company email rather than personal email ensures continuity even if personnel change.

Enter the complete postal address where official documents should be sent. Include building/floor details, street name, landmark, city, state, and pincode. This address will be used for sending physical policy documents and legal notices.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 304, Industrial Estate, Near Railway Station, Andheri East, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400069

questions.guidance_text: Provide the exact physical address of the property to be insured. This should include plot/survey number, building name, street, area, city, and pincode. For industrial areas, include the estate name and unit number. Accurate location helps in risk assessment and claim verification.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Plot No. 45, Phase II, MIDC Industrial Area, Pune, Maharashtra - 411018

questions.guidance_text: Indicate how many separate physical locations need coverage under this policy. Multiple locations can be covered under a single policy for administrative convenience. Each location will need separate risk assessment and sum insured declaration.

List each additional location on a new line with complete address. Include the type of property at each location (factory, warehouse, office, etc.) and approximate value. This helps insurers assess cumulative risk and determine if floater coverage is beneficial.
questions.placeholder:
Location 2: Warehouse at Plot 12, GIDC, Vapi - 396195
Location 3: Office at Business Plaza, Bandra West, Mumbai - 400050

questions.guidance_text: Floater coverage allows you to move stocks between declared locations without informing the insurer each time. This is cost-effective for businesses with multiple warehouses or frequent stock transfers. Choose 'Yes' if you regularly move inventory between locations.

Select the primary use of your property as it significantly affects risk assessment and premium. Manufacturing units typically have higher risk than offices due to machinery and processes. If your property has mixed usage, select the option that represents the highest risk activity.

Enter the number of years since the building was constructed or last underwent major structural renovation. Newer buildings (less than 10 years) often qualify for better rates due to modern construction standards and lower risk of structural issues.

questions.question_text: Is property located in Bhiwandi area?
questions.guidance_text: Bhiwandi is a major warehousing hub but historically has higher fire risk due to dense storage facilities and past incidents. Properties in Bhiwandi may attract higher premiums. Be transparent as incorrect declaration can lead to claim rejection.

Select the date from which you want insurance coverage to begin. This typically aligns with your current policy expiry or immediate coverage needs. Ensure there's no gap between old and new policy to maintain continuous coverage history.

Standard fire policies are typically issued for one year, though longer terms may be available. The end date should be one year from the start date for annual policies. Multi-year policies may offer premium discounts but require longer commitment.

questions.question_text: Total Sum Insured for Top Location (₹)
questions.guidance_text: Enter the total value of assets at your highest-valued location including building, machinery, and stocks. This should reflect current market/replacement value, not book value. Underinsuring to save premium can result in proportionate claim settlement, leaving you with significant losses.

Enter the current reconstruction cost of the building structure excluding land value. This should include civil work, plumbing, electrical fittings, and permanent fixtures. Use current construction rates in your area, not the original purchase price or book value.

Declare the current replacement value of all manufacturing equipment, production machinery, and industrial tools. Include installation costs and import duties if applicable. For imported machinery, use current import cost including exchange rate changes, not historical purchase price.

Include office furniture, computers, air conditioners, office equipment, and movable fixtures. These are items not permanently attached to the building but essential for operations. Use current market prices for similar new items, applying appropriate depreciation.

Declare the maximum stock value you expect to hold at any time during the policy period, including raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods. Consider seasonal peaks and include goods held on consignment. Underestimating can leave you exposed during high inventory periods.

Include any other insurable assets not covered above such as specialized tools, dies, moulds, or valuable documents. Specify the nature of these assets in the remarks section. These might need separate valuation certificates for high-value items.
List and describe the other assets you're insuring. Be specific about their nature, quantity, and importance to your operations. This helps insurers understand the risk and ensures proper coverage.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Specialized testing equipment, imported dies and moulds, architectural drawings and blueprints

questions.question_text: Do you currently have Fire Insurance?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you have active fire insurance or had one recently. Continuous insurance history often results in better premiums and shows risk awareness. If your policy expired recently, you may still benefit from renewal discounts if the gap is minimal.

Provide the name of your current or most recent insurance company. This helps in porting benefits like No Claim Bonus and understanding your coverage history. Insurers may request your claims experience certificate from the previous insurer.
questions.placeholder: e.g., New India Assurance Co. Ltd.

questions.guidance_text: Enter your existing or most recent policy number for reference. This helps track your insurance history and may expedite the underwriting process. Keep your policy document handy as you may need to provide a copy.

questions.question_text: Any claims in the past 5 years?
questions.guidance_text: Declare all fire, theft, or natural calamity claims made in the last 5 years across all your properties. Being transparent about claims history is crucial as insurers verify this information. Claim-free history may qualify you for no-claim discounts.

For each claim, provide the date, cause of loss, claimed amount, and settled amount. Include steps taken to prevent recurrence. This information helps insurers assess risk improvements and may influence premium calculations.
questions.placeholder: e.g., March 2023 - Electrical short circuit caused minor fire, Claimed: ₹500,000, Settled: ₹450,000, Installed new electrical panels with circuit breakers

questions.guidance_text: Select all fire safety equipment installed at your premises. Having proper fire protection systems can significantly reduce your premium (up to 50% discount for sprinkler systems). Regular maintenance certificates for these systems may be requested during underwriting.

questions.question_text: Is property exposed to STFI risks?
questions.guidance_text: STFI stands for Storm, Tempest, Flood, and Inundation. Select 'Yes' if your property is in a flood-prone area, near water bodies, or in regions with frequent cyclones. Properties in coastal areas or near rivers typically have STFI exposure requiring additional coverage.

If you have multiple buildings on the same premises, enter the minimum distance between them in meters. Greater separation (typically over 50 meters) reduces fire spread risk and may qualify for premium discounts. Leave blank if you have a single building.

Describe properties and activities within 100 meters of your premises. Mention any high-risk neighbors like chemical factories, petrol pumps, or timber yards. Also note if you're in a residential area or isolated location, as this affects fire spread risk and emergency response time.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Located in industrial estate with textile units on both sides, residential colony 200m away, no hazardous industries nearby

questions.guidance_text: Enter the distance to the nearest operational fire station via motorable road. Properties within 5 km typically get better rates due to faster emergency response. If over 8 km, insurers may require additional fire safety measures or charge higher premiums.

FLEXA (Fire, Lightning, Explosion, and Aircraft damage) covers only basic perils. If you don't need extended coverage for riots, strikes, or natural calamities, you can request a FLEXA-only policy at discounted rates. Standard discount ranges from 10-15% based on risk profile.

Select any additional coverages you need beyond standard fire and special perils. These are typically offered as add-ons with separate premiums. Business Interruption coverage is highly recommended as it covers lost profits during restoration after a claim.

Mention any specific coverage needs, special conditions, or unique aspects of your business that insurers should know. Include any risk improvements planned, seasonal variations in stock, or special security arrangements. This helps insurers provide accurate and comprehensive quotes.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We maintain 24x7 security, CCTV surveillance, and monthly fire drills. Planning to install sprinkler system by March 2025.

questions.guidance_text: Upload your current or most recent fire insurance policy document if available. This helps insurers understand your existing coverage and provide comparable or enhanced protection. Accepted formats: PDF, JPG, PNG (max 5MB).

For properties with sum insured above ₹5 crores, a valuation certificate from a registered valuer may be required. This ensures adequate coverage and smooth claim settlement. Recent valuations (within 2 years) from chartered engineers or approved valuers are preferred.

Upload your latest audited balance sheet and P&L statement. These help insurers assess your business stability and determine appropriate coverage for stocks and business interruption. Financial statements within the last 12 months are preferred.

A building layout showing fire safety equipment locations, emergency exits, and storage areas helps in risk assessment. For large properties or complex layouts, this document can expedite underwriting and may help negotiate better terms.
